div.l: ¶ Here begynneth þe ꝓprologe of þe Reves tale
Whan folke hauen laghen at þis nyce case
Off Absolon̄ and hende Nicolas
Diuerse folke diuersly þei seide
But for þe mor͗e parte þei logh and pleide
Ne at þis tale I saugh no man hym greue
But if it wer͗e only Oswalde þe Reue
By cause he was of Carpenters crafte
A litell ire is in his herte lafte
He gan to grucche and blamed it a lite
So the yk qduod he full wele kouothe I ȝowe quyte
With bleryng of a proude myllers eye
Yf þat me liste to speke of Ribaldrye
But I am olde me liste not pleye for age
Grasse tyme is done my foder is forrage
This white top writeth myn olde ȝeres
Myn herte is also mowled as myn heres
But if I far͗e as doith an open̄ ers
That ilke fruyte is eủer lenger þe wers
Till it be roten̄ in Mulloke or in stree
We olde men I drede so fare we
Till we be roten̄ kan̄ we not be ripe
We hoppen̄ all weye whil þe world will pipe
For in our͗e will þer stiketh eủer a nayll
To haue an hoor͗e her͗e and a grene tayll
As hath a leke for þogh our͗e myȝht be gone
Our͗e wille desireth folye eủer in one
For whan̄ we may not done þan woll we speke
Ȝit in our͗e Asshyn olde is fir͗e y reke
Four͗e gledes hauen̄ we which I schall devise
Auᵃauntyng lying Anger couetise
This iiij sparkles longeth vn to elde
Our͗e olde lymes mowe wel bene vnwelde
But will ne schall not faillen þat is sothe
And ȝet haf I al weye a coltes tothe
Als mony a ȝer͗e as it is passed henne
Sen þat my tap of lyffe began to renne
For sikerly whan I was borne anone
Deth drough þe tappe of lyffe and lete it gone
And eủer sithen hath so þe tappe y ronne
Till þat almoste all empty is þe tonne
The streme of liffe nowe droppeth on þe chymbe
The sely tonge may wele rynge and clymbe
Of wrecchednes þat passed is full yor͗e
With olde folke saue dotage is no more
When þat our͗e oste had hard þis sermonynge
He gan̄ to speken̄ als lordly as a kynge
